content: Introduction:
Begin by emphasizing the importance of being able to identify coins and bills in our daily lives. Explain that knowing the value of money helps us make smart decisions when spending and saving.
Identifying Coins:
Coins are small, metallic objects used as money. They come in different sizes, shapes, and colors. Let's learn about some common coins and their values.
Penny:
The penny is a small, copper-colored coin.
It is worth 1 cent.
The front side usually features the profile of a former president, while the back side often depicts the Lincoln Memorial.
Nickel:
The nickel is a slightly larger coin with a silvery color.
It is worth 5 cents.
The front side typically shows the profile of a former president, while the back side may feature images like Thomas Jefferson's Monticello.
Dime:
The dime is a small, silver-colored coin.
It is worth 10 cents.
The front side usually displays the profile of a former president, while the back side often showcases an image of Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Quarter:
The quarter is a larger coin with a silvery color.
It is worth 25 cents.
The front side typically features the profile of a former president, while the back side may depict different designs, such as state emblems or national parks.
Identifying Bills:
Bills, also known as banknotes or paper money, are rectangular pieces of paper issued by the government as a form of currency. Let's learn about some common bills and their values.
$1 Bill:
The $1 bill is the smallest denomination of U.S. currency.
It features the portrait of George Washington, the first president of the United States, on the front side.
The back side often showcases the Great Seal of the United States or other historical symbols.
$5 Bill:
The $5 bill is slightly larger than the $1 bill.
It features the portrait of Abraham Lincoln, the 16th president of the United States, on the front side.
The back side often depicts the Lincoln Memorial.
$10 Bill:
The $10 bill is larger than the $5 bill.
It features the portrait of Alexander Hamilton, one of the Founding Fathers of the United States, on the front side.
The back side often shows images related to Hamilton's life and contributions.
$20 Bill:
The $20 bill is larger than the $10 bill.
It features the portrait of Andrew Jackson, the 7th president of the United States, on the front side.
The back side often depicts the White House.
